FacilityName: Rich Products Corporation - New Britain Facility

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: City of New Britain Fire Department

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Rich Products Corporation's (RPC's) New Britain, CT location ("Site") has developed this program in accordance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA's) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (CAPP) of the Clean Air Act, as amended (CAAA), a.k.a., the Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule, which is codified at 40 CFR 68 and the United States Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (HHCs) standard (PSM standard), which is codified at 29 CFR 1910.119. The program is designed to inform all Site employees (hereafter referred to as Associates) of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates in the event of a release or spill (i.e., emergency response plan, management of change procedures, preventative maintenance program, associate training, etc.).

Additionally, RPC has developed and implemented the "Rich Products Corporation Standards for Safety Performance" which outlines the corporate policy for safety policies, safety procedures, and sample programs to be implemented at each Rich Products Corporation Facility.

RPC is guided by a set of core values that include:
  Cherish Our Culture - Work, learn and celebrate together;
   Innovate - Imagine what's possible and create what's valued;
   Be the Trusted First Choice - Listen, understand and deliver for customers like no other company;
   Better Our Communities - Devote time and talent where we work and live; and
   Do What's Right - No matter what.

RPC is committed to an irrevocable obligation to act responsibly in every decision made and with every person encountered.

RPC understands it is a trusted steward of its business relationships, its environment and the communities in which it serves.

RPC holds itself to the highest set of standards and is about doing what's right...no matter what.

FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The Site is located at 263 Myrtle Street

in the city of New Britain, Hartford County, Connecticut. The facility is 191,330 Sq/Ft.  It is near a residential neighborhood and other businesses. The Facility normally operates 5-6 days per week with two production shift and one clean up shift.  

The Site manufactures Frozen Ice Cream Cakes.   

As part of the Site's refrigeration system, which is used to freeze the Ice Cream Cakes assembly and for shipment, the Site handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance/highly hazardous chemical as defined in the USEPA's RMP Rule and OSHA's PSM standard, in an amount exceeding the regulatory threshold for anhydrous ammoniain a single process, i.e., the Site's refrigeration system. The Facility is registered to Program Level 3 under the USEPA CAPP program.

The anhydrous ammonia, which is liquefied under pressure, is contained in various vessels, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the refrigeration system. The Facility's engine room houses the majority of the refrigeration machinery.

"ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION
While there are few long-term environmental consequences to ammonia use, it can present health hazards if handled improperly. RPC has developed a comprehensive safety program in compliance with OSHA and EPA requirements to ensure the responsible management of the ammonia onsite (the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program, respectively). All refrigeration Associates receive operator training, safe work practices training and training on the standard operating procedures (SOPs). Safety meetings are conducted to further protect Associates and the community as a whole.

The Facility's prevention program is designed to inform all Associates of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates and the community in the event of a release or spill.

The Facility endeavors to eliminate accidents and health hazards to Associates, customers, and the community

by having procedures in place to provide Associates educational training, safe working conditions, and the means to increase awareness of potential dangers both on and off the job. RPC's objective is to prevent unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could potentially expose Associates and others to serious hazards. An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire system. Workplace and process safety are major concerns to management and Associates alike. The prevention and mitigation of unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could expose Associates and the community to serious hazards is of primary concern.

The Facility has incorporated many safety features in the design of the ammonia refrigeration system to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is an inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Facility's ammonia system is continuously monitored by automated control systems (including REMS) that shutdown pump and the components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the system is equipped with pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels and most, if not all, additional locations within the ammonia system where ammonia could become trapped.

RPC considers the health and safety of each Associate as its most important responsibility. It is our policy to provide a healthy and safe work environment. This facility follows operating practices that safeguard all associates and result in safe working conditions while maintaining efficient operations.

Safety is the responsibility of all Associates. Each associate is expected to comply with the requirements of RPC's Standards for Safety Performance. Management is responsible for the implementation, communication, documentation, and necessary training. The Associate is responsible for implementat

ion, communication, and practices of the program. Management is committed to maintain a high level of interest in health and safety throughout this facility. This commitment extends to the associates and their involvement in preventing accidents."

"RPC has established its Health and Safety Program to insure that:
   Associates work in a healthy and safe environment.
   Associates are trained on safe work practices.
   Associates practice safe work habits.
   Management and associates are both involved in the program.
   There is constant communication between all Associates on safety issues.
   Compliance with all regulatory agencies is maintained.

Major safety features at the Facility include:
   Installation of ammonia leak detectors in processing areas and the engine room
   Remote emergency shutdown switches for the refrigeration system
   Fire sprinklers throughout the Facility, and
   Component specific safety shutdowns of the refrigeration system.

In determining the worst case release scenario, from time to time, in order to conduct maintenance activities, Site Associates pumpout sections of the refrigeration system into the largest vessel. Subsequently, the Site has utilized the maximum amount the vessel would be filled to, during maintenance activities, rather than the amount normally present.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Within the previous five (5) years, there have been no accidental releases.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Facility is equipped with an emergency warning system. Alarms are placed throughout the Facility to alarm personnel of an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia or other emergencies that may be encountered. RPC has developed specific procedures to be followed in the event of release. These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so.

Plant personnel have received emergency response training as outlined in O

SHA's HAZWOPER regulation 29 CFR 1910.120 and other various rules and regulations.

The New Britain Fire Department has visited the facility to review the process operations, safety systems and discuss emergency response coordination. Additionally, Site Associates have made arrangements with a third-party emergency response contractor.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Facility recognizes that the implementation of this program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operation at the Facility. As such, the prevention program will evolve as RPC continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for the employees and the surrounding community."
